body:
You've done the impossible if you ever convince someone to question it though. Iirc the only one who ever did is Ron Paul and I am the only one I know who took him seriously.

This is probably one of the few areas where European countries are more libertarian than the US, though they still make it compulsory, just to a much lesser extent (which is still too much) and it's more career/gymnasium focused rather than drilling the 3 core academic subjects into everyone's skulls and "do everything we can to beat China's totally honest test scores!". I've heard a lot of them are at least willing to get rid of the disruptive students who don't want to be there too.

I'm not sure what happened that got so many people on board with this in the US, but you're automatically not worth listening to if you dare question it. I suppose it profits for the deep state somehow but I'm perplexed as to how. It sucks and ruins everyone's younger lives but at least Obama's term limit ended before he had his chance to make it even worse.
body_html:
You've done the impossible if you ever convince someone to question it though. Iirc the only one who ever did is Ron Paul and I am the only one I know who took him seriously.

This is probably one of the few areas where European countries are more libertarian than the US, though they still make it compulsory, just to a much lesser extent (which is still too much) and it's more career/gymnasium focused rather than drilling the 3 core academic subjects into everyone's skulls and "do everything we can to beat China's totally honest test scores!". I've heard a lot of them are at least willing to get rid of the disruptive students who don't want to be there too.

I'm not sure what happened that got so many people on board with this in the US, but you're automatically not worth listening to if you dare question it. I suppose it profits for the deep state somehow but I'm perplexed as to how. It sucks and ruins everyone's younger lives but at least Obama's term limit ended before he had his chance to make it even worse.

post.body: There is no ethical justification for instructors, educators, and administration to charge its students.
post.body_html: There is no ethical justification for instructors, educators, and administration to charge its students.
post.title: Education was and should be a voluntarist institution

body: I don't understand the premise of this opinion. I'm in the US, and they only institutions that charge students/parents directly are private schools and colleges. Public schooling is funded through school taxes, so it's free for 13 years to have a kid go to school, not counting lunch or field trip money of course. And honestly I think educators and admins deserve to be paid. They are trading their time and labor and deserve to be compensated for doing so. Otherwise only well off altruistic people, bums, and pensioners would teach which I think would negatively impact the quality of education. Someone doing a job for free and out of kindness has no incentive to do a good job since there will be no real repercussions that can negatively effect them. Just my two cents.
body_html: I don't understand the premise of this opinion. I'm in the US, and they only institutions that charge students/parents directly are private schools and colleges. Public schooling is funded through school taxes, so it's free for 13 years to have a kid go to school, not counting lunch or field trip money of course. And honestly I think educators and admins deserve to be paid. They are trading their time and labor and deserve to be compensated for doing so. Otherwise only well off altruistic people, bums, and pensioners would teach which I think would negatively impact the quality of education. Someone doing a job for free and out of kindness has no incentive to do a good job since there will be no real repercussions that can negatively effect them. Just my two cents.
